article.paragraph: Acampusis traditionally the land on which acollegeoruniversityand related institutional buildings are situated. A modern campus is a collection of buildings that belong to a given institution, either academic or non-academic. Usually a campus includeslibrarylibraries,lecturehalls,residence halls, student centers or dining halls, and park-like settings.
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The word derives from aLatinword for "field" and was first used to describe the grounds of the College of New Jersey (nowPrinceton University) during the 18th century.cite webhttp://www.etymonline.com/index.php?termDouglasHarperOnline Etymology Dictionary20 December 2013Campus (n.)Some other American colleges later adopted the word to describe individual fields at their own institutions, but "campus" did not yet describe the whole university property. A school might have one space called a campus, one called a field, and another called a yard.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The tradition of a campus begain with the medievalEuropeanuniversities where the students and teachers lived and worked together in acloisteredenvironment.cite bookhttp://books.google.co.uk/books?idAmerican Places: In Search of the Twenty-first Century CampusChapmanM. Perry7Greenwood Publishing Group2006The notion of the importance of the setting to academic life later migrated to America, and early colonial educational institutions were based on the Scottish and English collegiate system.
article.heading: Uses
article.paragraph: The meaning expanded to include the whole institutionalreal propertypropertyduring the 20th century, with the old meaning persisting into the 1950s in some places.
article.heading: Office buildings
article.paragraph: Sometimes the lands on which company office buildings sit, along with the buildings, are called campuses. TheMicrosoft CampusinRedmond, Washingtonis a good example. Hospitals, and even airports sometimes use the term to describe the territory of their facilities.
article.heading: Universities
article.paragraph: The word "campus" has also been applied to European universities, although most such institutions are characterized by ownership of individual buildings in urban settings rather than park-like lawns in which buildings are placed.cnMay 2015
